job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Madison, IN
pros: it is a very beautiful college, surrounded by mountains and rivers. Good working environment and lovely colleagues.
cons: I can not find any downsides working there.
Not many available hours. Meaning that you'll have to pick at least 2 jobs to work 10 hours.

job_title: Director of Experiential Learning in Hanover, IN
pros: Hanover is the oldest Liberal Arts College in the state of Indiana.  It has a rich academic history where students are encouraged to engage in deep learning.  Not only students are encouraged to learn, but faculty and staff are encouraged to be lifelong learners.  There are opportunities for faculty and staff to take classes, participate in campus culture such as plays, concerts, athletic events and the wellness program to name a few.  I have worked at several colleges and I can honestly say that working at Hanover has been one of the most professionally and personally rewarding institutions I have worked!
cons: The only con that I have is not really a con about the institution as it is about our current times.  As I started working at Hanover shortly before the recession, and as the recession has hit private academics hard with budget cuts and freezes, it has been difficult to see my  salary remain the same over the past several years and the cost of living go up.

review_title: No salary increase in three years, skimpy health insurance
pros: Good working conditions--beautiful campus. Faculty have much control over the content of their courses and even (within limits) over meeting times and courses offered. Cost of living is low in the area, which is scenic, but very rural and poor.
cons: Poor management on the part of the previous president led to a financial crisis. Despite increased enrollment, salaries have not increased and we are way behind average for schools of our type. Administration seems dismissive of faculty concerns about salary. Of course, the president and her VPs get paid a lot more than we do.

pros:
The College, founded in 1827,  is in a beautiful setting overlooking the Ohio River, and has great hiking trails. As with other academic settings, there are a lot of ways to become a part of the community though attending sporting or arts events, nearly all of which are free (as is parking!)

Given that Hanover is fairly isolated,  it is great that the College often employs both spouses, occasionally in the same academic department, but sometimes in different administrative offices.
cons: Hanover is fairly isolated, an hour from Louisville, KY; 90 minutes from Cincinnati, and about 2 hours from Indianapolis.

pros: Beautiful places to work, excellent benefits, fair pay, great community with lots of activities for employees
cons: hard work, a lot of mold in the building (which is bad for your health), very old buildings in need of a lot of maintenance, skunks running rampant and spraying your car

pros: Working at Hanover College was fine. It was a good student job that got me a steady source of income that helped me live comfortably on campus and pay for my art supplies.
cons: I didn't really think my boss was all that invested in helping me balance work and coursework, and the pay wasn't all that much honestly.

job_title: IT Help Desk in Hanover, IN
pros: Everyone was friendly, you really get to know those you work with
cons: Administration tends to gum things up
